
# Introduction to Terminal Charts and Graphs in C++

## What are terminal charts?

**Terminal charts** are visual representations of data created using text characters in the console window.

Instead of just displaying numbers:
```
Sales: 15, 23, 18, 30, 25
```

You can create a visual representation:
```
Month 1 sales: 15 units
Month 2 sales: 23 units
Month 3 sales: 18 units
Month 4 sales: 30 units
Month 5 sales: 25 units
```

---

**Why create charts in the terminal?**
- **Visualize data** - See patterns at a glance
- **Make programs more interesting** - Beyond just numbers
- **Practice loops and strings** - Apply what you've learned
- **Professional appearance** - More polished output
- **No graphics library needed** - Just cout and characters!

## Displaying data with for-each loops

Let's start by displaying data clearly using for-each loops.

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<int> sales = {15, 23, 18, 30, 25};
    
    cout << "===== SALES DATA =====" << endl;
    
    for (int sale : sales) {
        cout << "Sales: " << sale << " units" << endl;
    }
    
    return 0;
}
```

**Output:**
```
===== SALES DATA =====
Sales: 15 units
Sales: 23 units
Sales: 18 units
Sales: 30 units
Sales: 25 units
```

## Displaying parallel data with labels

When you have related data in multiple vectors, you can display them together using an index counter.

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<int> sales = {15, 23, 18, 30, 25};
    vector<string> months = {"Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May"};
    
    cout << "===== MONTHLY SALES =====" << endl;
    
    int index = 0;
    for (string month : months) {
        cout << month << ": " << sales[index] << " units" << endl;
        index++;
    }
    
    return 0;
}
```

---

**Output:**
```
===== MONTHLY SALES =====
Jan: 15 units
Feb: 23 units
Mar: 18 units
Apr: 30 units
May: 25 units
```

**How it works:**
- Create an index counter starting at 0
- For each month name, display it with the corresponding sales value
- Increment the index after each iteration

## Adding professional formatting

Use `setw()` and alignment to make your output look professional.

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <iomanip>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<int> scores = {85, 92, 78, 95, 88};
    vector<string> students = {"Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "Diana", "Eve"};
    
    cout << "===== TEST SCORES =====" << endl;
    
    int index = 0;
    for (string student : students) {
        cout << left << setw(10) << student 
             << right << setw(5) << scores[index] 
             << " points" << endl;
        index++;
    }
    
    return 0;
}
```

---

**Output:**
```
===== TEST SCORES =====
Alice        85 points
Bob          92 points
Charlie      78 points
Diana        95 points
Eve          88 points
```

## Working with multiple data types

For-each loops work with any vector type.

**String data:**

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<string> products = {"Laptop", "Mouse", "Keyboard", "Monitor", "Webcam"};
    
    cout << "===== PRODUCT LIST =====" << endl;
    
    int number = 1;
    for (string product : products) {
        cout << number << ". " << product << endl;
        number++;
    }
    
    return 0;
}
```

---

**Output:**
```
===== PRODUCT LIST =====
1. Laptop
2. Mouse
3. Keyboard
4. Monitor
5. Webcam
```

---

**Double data with formatting:**

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <iomanip>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<double> prices = {899.99, 24.50, 79.99, 299.99, 89.95};
    vector<string> items = {"Laptop", "Mouse", "Keyboard", "Monitor", "Webcam"};
    
    cout << "===== PRICE LIST =====" << endl;
    cout << fixed << setprecision(2);
    
    int index = 0;
    for (string item : items) {
        cout << left << setw(12) << item 
             << "$" << right << setw(7) << prices[index] << endl;
        index++;
    }
    
    return 0;
}
```

---

**Output:**
```
===== PRICE LIST =====
Laptop      $ 899.99
Mouse       $  24.50
Keyboard    $  79.99
Monitor     $ 299.99
Webcam      $  89.95
```

## Creating tables with borders

Use the `string()` function to create lines and borders.

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
#include <iomanip>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<int> votes = {45, 38, 52, 30};
    vector<string> candidates = {"Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "Dave"};
    
    int width = 40;
    
    // Top border
    cout << "+" << string(width, '-') << "+" << endl;
    
    // Title
    string title = "ELECTION RESULTS";
    int padding = (width - title.length()) / 2;
    cout << "|" << string(padding, ' ') << title 
         << string(width - padding - title.length(), ' ') << "|" << endl;
    
    cout << "+" << string(width, '-') << "+" << endl;
    
    // Data rows
    int index = 0;
    for (string candidate : candidates) {
        cout << "| " << left << setw(15) << candidate 
             << right << setw(5) << votes[index] 
             << " votes           |" << endl;
        index++;
    }
    
    // Bottom border
    cout << "+" << string(width, '-') << "+" << endl;
    
    return 0;
}
```

---

**Output:**
```
+----------------------------------------+
|          ELECTION RESULTS              |
+----------------------------------------+
| Alice             45 votes           |
| Bob               38 votes           |
| Carol             52 votes           |
| Dave              30 votes           |
+----------------------------------------+
```

---

**How it works:**
- `string(width, '-')` creates a string of dashes
- Calculate padding to center the title
- Use setw() to align data in columns

## Calculating statistics with for-each loops

You can perform calculations on your data using for-each loops.

**Calculating total:**

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<int> sales = {150, 200, 175, 225, 190};
    
    int total = 0;
    for (int sale : sales) {
        total += sale;
    }
    
    cout << "Total Sales: " << total << " units" << endl;
    
    return 0;
}
```

**Output:**
```
Total Sales: 940 units
```

---

**Calculating average:**

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <iomanip>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<int> scores = {85, 92, 78, 95, 88};
    
    int total = 0;
    for (int score : scores) {
        total += score;
    }
    
    double average = static_cast<double>(total) / scores.size();
    
    cout << fixed << setprecision(2);
    cout << "Total Points: " << total << endl;
    cout << "Average Score: " << average << endl;
    
    return 0;
}
```

**Output:**
```
Total Points: 438
Average Score: 87.60
```

## Complete example - Sales dashboard

Here's a comprehensive example combining multiple techniques.

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <iomanip>
#include <string>
using namespace std;

int main() {
    vector<int> sales = {150, 200, 175, 225, 190};
    vector<string> months = {"Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May"};
    
    cout << "========================================" << endl;
    cout << "       QUARTERLY SALES REPORT           " << endl;
    cout << "========================================" << endl;
    cout << endl;
    
    // Display monthly data
    cout << "MONTHLY SALES DATA" << endl;
    cout << "----------------------------------------" << endl;
    
    int index = 0;
    for (string month : months) {
        cout << left << setw(8) << month 
             << right << setw(8) << sales[index] << " units" << endl;
        index++;
    }
    
    cout << endl;
    
    // Calculate statistics
    int total = 0;
    for (int sale : sales) {
        total += sale;
    }
    
    double average = static_cast<double>(total) / sales.size();
    
    // Display summary
    cout << "SUMMARY" << endl;
    cout << "----------------------------------------" << endl;
    cout << fixed << setprecision(2);
    cout << "Total Sales:    " << right << setw(6) << total << " units" << endl;
    cout << "Average Sales:  " << right << setw(6) << average << " units" << endl;
    cout << "Number of Months: " << sales.size() << endl;
    cout << "========================================" << endl;
    
    return 0;
}
```

---

**Output:**
```
========================================
       QUARTERLY SALES REPORT           
========================================

MONTHLY SALES DATA
----------------------------------------
Jan        150 units
Feb        200 units
Mar        175 units
Apr        225 units
May        190 units

SUMMARY
----------------------------------------
Total Sales:       940 units
Average Sales:   188.00 units
Number of Months: 5
========================================
```

## Tips for effective charts

**1. Choose appropriate scaling**
- Too many characters = too wide
- Too few characters = hard to see differences
- Common scales: 1, 5, 10, 50, 100

**2. Add clear labels**
- Chart title
- Axis labels
- Data values
- Units of measurement

---

**3. Use consistent spacing**
- Align columns with setw()
- Keep bar spacing uniform
- Use fixed widths for labels

**4. Include a legend when needed**
- Explain what characters represent
- Show the scale
- Define abbreviations

---

**5. Test with different data**
- Small values
- Large values
- Equal values
- Edge cases

## Common mistakes and fixes

**Mistake 1: Wrong vector access**

```cpp
// BAD - Using loop variable instead of index
int index = 0;
for (string name : names) {
    cout << name << ": " << scores[0];  // Always prints first score!
    index++;
}
```

**Fix:**
```cpp
// GOOD - Use the index variable
int index = 0;
for (string name : names) {
    cout << name << ": " << scores[index];  // Correct!
    index++;
}
```

---

**Mistake 4: Not initializing accumulator**

```cpp
// BAD - total not initialized
int total;
for (int value : values) {
    total += value;  // Undefined behavior!
}
```

**Fix:**
```cpp
// GOOD - Initialize to zero
int total = 0;  // Always initialize!
for (int value : values) {
    total += value;
}
```

# Key Takeaways

## 1. Professional formatting combines setw(), alignment, and borders to create clear displays

Use `left` and `right` manipulators with `setw()` to align columns: `cout << left << setw(10) << label << right << setw(8) << value;`. Create borders with `string(width, '-')` to make sections visually distinct. Add titles, spacing, and consistent alignment throughout. Fixed precision with `fixed` and `setprecision(2)` ensures clean numeric output. These formatting techniques transform simple data into professional-looking reports and dashboards.
